abstracts.cdata!:
The Municipal Development Project in the
            State of Rio Grande do Sul, known locally as the PIMES
            project, was the first Bank-supported operation in the State
            of Rio Grande do Sul (RGS) aimed at reforming
            municipalities. The Project used the provision of urban
            infrastructure finance to leverage municipal management
            improvements and introduced a new line of credit with
            quasi-market lending terms and conditions. Its design was
            based upon the Parana Municipal Development Project (Ln.
            3100-BR) appraised four months earlier, but implemented in
            quite different circumstances. Similar follow-on projects
            were later approved for the states of Minas Gerais (Ln.
            3639-BR) and Bahia (Ln.4140-BR). Tlhe project's
            objectives were to: (i) improve the managerial and
            institutional capacity and fiscal efficiency of RGS
            municipalities and state agencies. (ii) Provide basic
            economic and social infrastructure in urban areas. (iii)
            Decentralize urban administration and financial management.
            (iv) Improve targeting of urban programs to lower-income
            populations. (v) Create and strengthen a State urban
            development fund (FUNDOPIMES). In support of these
            objectives, Bank Loan proceeds were on-lent to
            municipalities, their water companies, and the RGS water
            company, CORSAN, to finance their priority investments. In
            addition, intemal management improvements were to be carried
            out. Moreover, the rigorous terms and conditions of
            FUNDOPIMES' lending were themselves an incentive for
            municipalities to reform their finances in order to be able
            to service their project debts comfortably. The kind of
            investments foreseen under the project included street
            paving, drainage, basic sanitation, day care centers and
            health posts. PIMES supported municipal efforts to improve
            their management directly through its institutional
            development (ID) component.
